reviewText:
Wow! I just finished the game and it was an awesome experience!
Without words, the story is told visually of 2 dragon flies in a world of fantasy, magic, danger and sadness as you click onto and drag key objects in sync with the awesome soundtrack to make the story progress. It's pretty much a rhythm game.
Though the game is short, about 50 minutes to complete, it was worth every minute.
The devs at SuperChop Games really blew me away with this game and I look forward to seeing what else they will bring in the future.
My girl is gonna love this game. Then she will probably cry when she gets to the end. :)

reviewText: This is the greatest proof that a good game can be all about the experience. It's artsy without being pretentious, and it's fun in its simplicity. I've been enjoying the soundtrack for quite a while, but the game as a whole provides an overwhelming experience if you're open to it. I cry every time. And I love it -- makes me feel alive.

reviewText:
Well, this was a beautiful and mesmerizing journey. A musical adventure where you follow a pair of mayflies (or butterflies...something like that) as they try to keep each other alive and express the joy of their love for one another. Along the way, they find allies in beetles and bees, and fight off a gigantic boombox (yes, the stereo type) carrying spider.

Visually, this game is stunning. The nature of the gameplay means there will be a ton of actual fireworks and such, with a lot of cool imagery that comes with that, along with flowers, and a ton of other great stuff to look at. I suppose you also go through the seasons as well although this is a bit more ambiguous.

There is no dialogue. The music conveys all the meaning in this one. Speaking of the music, as a game based around a musical journey, you would expect the tunes to be stellar, and they in fact are that and more. This is the type of soundtrack you could easily jam often. Really great sounding music. The way this game is presented musically reminds me a lot of Karmaflow, so I wonder if it is the same people, although at first glance, it doesnt appear to be.

So, what is the game itself? Baically, it is a speedrun click fest. The music and the clicking start out slow and manageable, but as the music picks up tempo, so to does the clicking. Where it isnt clicking, it is click and drag. I'm not very good at this personally, so I didnt manage anything even resembling a perfect sequence, lol. It isnt required for the story progression, but some of the achievements seem to be tied to this. Also, there is apparently a secret level, but I havent found it yet. So, after your first playthrough, it definitely becomes a game of skill and speed.

So, anyway, all told, I think this game warrants 9 bad ♥♥♥ riffs as a pair of butterfly dragons swirl and fly through the air while fireworks explode around them, out of 10.

Additionally, I would definitely assign this must own status for pretty much everybody. I cant imagine somebody playing this and not enjoying it.
voteText: 19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
God damn, this game is way more awesome than it sounds or looks like it should be.

I can't describe the gameplay better than the description, and I can't describe what happens in the game without ruining everything, but let me just say that this was a fantastic experience with excellent music, shockingly epic (a word that gets abused too often but deserves a spot here) visual accompaniment, and a bizarrely engaging story.

The gameplay itself isn't really anything special, but the music and pace of the whole thing are so amazing you won't even notice, but for the sake of comparison, it's a little like osu! except... not... Yeah, that's as good as I can get.

Oh, and the music sounds a lot like the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, so there's that.

I think out of all the little indie games that've come out over the past few months, over-saturating the Steam storefront with amateur nonsense, this is the one that most deserves to be played.

Good job, SuperChop.

reviewText:
Ephemerid: A Musical Adventure
9 / 10

Follow The May Fly for a day. Point click and flick to Great Guitar Rock Music. First playthrough 50 minutes....

The art, the color palette, and the animations are fantastic. The music and the soundscape rise and fall like a true Rock Opera. This soundtrack reminded me of why I started playing Drums in the first place.... Joy.

Chapeau.

Operational Notes: I had to turn up the mouse sensitivity in the Control Panel to keep up with the Mayfly.... and there is a speed control on the turn table to slow the game down ; )

reviewText: Ephemerid embodies the spirt of a fantastic musically driven game. Every track demonstrates both a level of musical understanding and emotional delivery that I've not seen in video games in years. The story told is beautiful, and can be easily consumed in an hour or so. No fail states makes it just that much better.\n\n100% recommended to fans of musical story telling, rhythm games, or people that are looking for something to make them cry. Because this will.

reviewText:
I just finished playing the game, and I thought I'd review it, since it could be helpful for potential buyers.

First of all, the description on the store page is spot-on. It's part rhythm game, part point & click and well, part rock opera (I guess). It is kinda lackluster in all three, though, but it's still worth it IMO.

It's a pretty game, but I'd say that it's not as much of a game as it is a visual experience. Graphics and story are really pretty. It kept me interested all the way through and I finished it in one go (it's short).

My only problem with the game is that I think this was clearly meant to be played with a touchscreen, so if you want to get it and it's available for tablets or ipad, then I'd highly suggest you get it on those platforms instead.

The game itself is kinda short, but it's lovely. I got the same feeling I get with Cirque du soleil".  I mean shows like Varekai
date: where you get a story told through music and performances.\n\nMy only complaint aside from the touchscreen issue
recommended: is that the music itself is kinda lackluster. It's low budget and loaded with electric guitars that didn't really make sense to me. It matched the feel of the game at some points
hoursPlayed: but most of the time it felt off.\n\nI had a good time
voteText: but... I've had better for the same price
helpfulPercent: and if I could go back in time and get it on my iPad
votesHelpful: I would.\n\nIf you have a kid
votesTotal: I think they would enjoy it a lot on an iPad or something similar
votesFunny: mostly because you can't win or lose... you just follow the story
commentsCount: and you can replay levels afterwards.\n\nI'd give it a 6/10 for what it is."

reviewText:
Ephemerid might not have the strongest game component to it - but the art is stylistically gorgeous papercraft, the game is mostly you playing a visualiser through drag or tap mechanics, and the music is quite varied and awesome, and sound effects are papercrafty as well. This is a really fun record/album long game, with a soundtrack that is really worth listening to. It might not be a AAA title, but it's probably the best music game I've heard or seen, and it's got one of the best indie soundtracks in the business.

Also, who can resist getting this after hearing Jared and Jesse's renditions of the songs with their actual lyrics?

Well made and put together, well worth getting both the game and the soundtrack!

reviewText:
[português abaixo]

Ephemerid is more of a musical experience than a game. The gamepley consist on moving your mouse, clicking and draging in the right time, mostly in the rythmic beat of a song, with a lot of visual clues. For the most of the game, you have are not punished for missing a click, or even all the clicks. You could just sit back, listen to the great soundtrack (worth buying it!) and watch the story unfolds in front of you, all with a great artwork of paper cuts and lights. If you like a challenge, there's a secret level almost impossible to beat, and achievements that will make you do the entire game without any miss.
I had one major bug that stopped the game from working during a few days, but after the creator identifying the problem, everything was solved and I could play this masterpiece once again. The step by step for the problem solution, if you happen to stumble by the same bug as I did, is in the forums.

___________________________________________________________________________________


Ephemerid é mais uma experiência muscial do que um jogo. O gameplay consite em mover seu mouse, clicar e arrastar, quase que sempre ao ritmo da batida de uma música, com muitas dicas visuais que auxiliam a executar os movimentos no momento certo. Durante a maior parte do jogo, não há punição para errar um click, ou mesmo errar todos os clicks de uma fase. Você pode apenas sentar, escutar a ótima trilha sonora (vale a pena comprar!) e assistir o desenrolar da estória, construída com um impressionante trabalho artístco de cortes e dobraduras de papel e luzes. Se você gosta de um desafio, existe uma fase secreta quase impossível de terminar, e conquistas que exigem que você refaça cada fase sem errar nenhuma nota.
Eu só tive um bug que me impediu de jogar por alguns dias, mas depois que o criador identificou o problema, tudo foi resolvido e eu pude voltar a jogar essa obra de arte. O passo a passo para a solução do problema, se você por acaso esbarrar no mesmo bug que eu, se encontra nas discussões, em inglês; mas ficarei feliz de ajudar alguém que precise de tradução.

reviewText: This game made me fall in love with a mayfly.\n\nIt's short, yes, but every second of it is enjoyable. Personally, I prefer a short but well-crafted game to a long one, and this little gem is one of the better purchases I've made in a long while. The music is excellent, the visuals are beautiful, and the gameplay is clean and polished. It's always clear waht you're meant to do, without any instructions, and it requires enough skill that you'll want to go back and perfect it - especially since the music is so epic. I'll admit that I got this in a bundle, but having played it through once, I would happily pay full price for it. It is worth it.

reviewText: Ephemerid is the sort of game that reminds you that you can, in fact, still feel joy. It tells its story about small, fragile creatures through cutscenes and minigames devoid of text. In this way, it's very reminiscent of Botanicula. Almost all of the gameplay involves rhythm or incorporates music in some other way. The minigames themselves are almost beside the point; it's the way they are presented to you that makes this game something wonderful: beautiful music, a papercraft world, and a touching story. This journey takes under an hour, and honestly, it didn't need to be any longer than that. I have no doubt that I'll play and enjoy this again.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not sure exactly what I was expecting here, but what I got was pretty janky. Ephemerid: A Music Adventure is self-described as a rock opera that is more of an experience, than a game. This sounded like something I would enjoy, but it turned out to be much more of a click fest that was anything but synchronized with the music.

What I think it is trying to be is some sort of interactive Fantasia which is a super cool idea. It failed pretty miserably in the execution, unfortunately.

Many 'scenes' just went on forever on a kind of loop with spam clicking. Don't even get me started on the biology here (and yes, that is a legitimate argument since it is directly referencing ephemeridae (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ephemeridae)). Nothing really made sense as far as the life cycle of the mayfly that you are controlling, and I'll just leave it at that.

Pros:
+Awesome idea that would be super cool if pulled off correctly.

Cons:
-Most importantly - music is real 'meh'
-Spam clicking ruins it. My wife and I spent a disproportionate amount of time trying to figure out if the clicking is in rhythym (or in synch) with the music. Pretty sure its not.
-Artwork is fairly bland.

I refunded. It just wasn't worth the money, in the state its in.
voteText: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I had never heard of this game before, however I saw it on sale and since I’m really into rhythm and music games I decided to give this one a try. Then I missed a note and I noticed the music didn’t stop, nor did the game, nor did anything; then I just let the game run by itself without touching the mouse and while it kept going  without any input I said to myself “This is going to be one of those days isn’t it?”.

Ok, fine, whatever I decided to play along and honestly I found it to be extremely disappointing in almost every aspect “BUT YOU ONLY PLAYED HALF AN HOUR!” you say, BUT THAT’S HOW MUCH THIS GAME LASTS! I answer,  and that’s just the tip of the iceberg with this game.

Ok first let’s talk about the positives, the visuals are pretty and the story is told without a single word of dialog and even though it’s a pretty simple story line about two dragonflies falling in love but it’s still told in a well-done matter. The tempo is also spot-on and the notes are very easy to tell apart from the background, even though they take different shapes and forms with each stage.

And now for the negatives: Everything else. As I said in the beginning you can’t really die or lose, ever, and as such the game has limited replay value. You can only get an extra stage if you get every single note without missing a beat, that’s all the replay value this game has and I can’t be bothered.

Why?

Because the game is quite obviously a poorly done Ipad/Tablet port, there’s only one resolution and the mouse controllers are incredibly wonky, in other words, if you don’t have a touch screen don’t buy this game. This makes it very hard for me to replay the game as I don’t have a touchscreen monitor, nor am I planning on buying one sometime in the future and I really despise the mouse implementation in this game, I REALLY do.

The music isn’t something that I would write home about either, to me it felt like an amateur composer made the entire score much like I did scores when I started playing piano “Check it out mom I can play from C# to B and back!”. There was only one song that I liked from the soundtrack, ONE, which is not something I usually say about rhythm games.

Finally there’s the stages, I can sum them up like this: one stage is recycled three times and one of them is… Do you remember that mind-numbingly boring lawn mowing game where you do nothing but mow the lawn? That mini-game is in this game as a stage, yes, really.

Can I recommend this game to anyone?
Actually, yes, I can. The whole time I was playing I was thinking that I would’ve enjoyed this game a lot if I was about 15 or 17 years younger,  so if you’re a parent looking for a game without any violence for his kid I can fully recommend this one.

I get the feeling with the overall positive reception of this game I’m going to end up receiving some very… interesting mail in the near future but I don’t care, this game is clearly not for me and I don't think it was worth the three dollars I paid for it.

reviewText: A short and fun game, which I think is designed simply guide you through a beautiful story (or a story supposed to be beautiful). The game play is really simple, although I didn't find any instructions about what you are supposed to do. If you love music, you may have some good time in this game.\nA bit disappointed with one thing: some music pieces are not compatible with the theme. Rather than pop or disco, I expected more New Age and classic genre.

reviewText: I started the game just to farm some cards, but after 5 minutes I thought I'd exit the game after the end of the first chapter. But it didn't came. And after 20 minutes I couldn't leave the poor mayfly alone, so I kept playing and playing... until suddenly I was reading the credits.\n\nGood game for less than 2-3 bucks or a bundle.

reviewText: I loved every minute of this game. It's one of the most unique experiences I've had playing a video game. The art style is fantastic, and the soundtrack is amazing. A full play through will net in at just under an hour but in that short time you get a full rock opera about a mayfly and his adventures. Do not pass up this game.

reviewText: This is a FANTASTIC game.  Straightforward, amazing music, charming and well done papercraft visuals, and just plain old FUN.\n\nThis was obviously a game best played on a touch screen, but not impossible as a point-and-click.  I could play this over and over just for the music.  You can tell the love that went into this game and it really pays off.  I can't recommend this enough, especially to players who appreciate art and music.

It's a story about two dragonflies, their adventure, enemies.
It's a music/rythm game, click to the music, which has nice electric guitar in it.
The game itself is short, little under an hour to complete.
You can set the speed from turtle to rabbit, making it very challenging.
I'm very pleased I bought this.

reviewText: This , , , this game, almost had me cry tears of joy.  I don't even know what to classify it as truly.  It's just beautiful with awesome music and art.  It sucks you in.  Usually I dislike fullscreen games because I mult task and tend to put them up right away when I start to play and realize what they are.  This one had to glued to the monitor, well until a friend messaged me and messed me up closing the game by mistake.  Long story short . . . it's a unique and magical experiance in my eyes.  Worth every penny.

reviewText:
A really cool rhythm game, especially if you like crazy power rock music. It's amazing. The music alone is worth the buy.
The visuals are impressive. Everything looks like papercraft, but moves very smoothly, and some of the rhythm elements are pretty clever.
It is on the short side, though. I finished in about 45 minutes. Maybe grab it on sale if you can.
I also teared up at the end, but that is totally subjective and I am a complete sap.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I felt my heart ache and tears flow at the very end...

The start of this musical journey of a mayfly seemed intriguing and slightly uncertain at first, but I soon got the hang of it with no words required. I began to realise by the third track that it was not just a melodious flutter amongst foliages; an actual story was being told to me. Despite its child-like exterior of a papercrafted environment, I somehow related closely to it and the many symbolisms of friendship, courage, struggles, and sacrifice. The ending was unexpected, yet bittersweet.

After all, it's but a mayfly...

--

In case I was a tad too poetic and you didn't understand whatever I just said:

The game is simple but interactively unique, has a beautiful soundtrack, an interesting environment, good story, and overall, I am satisfied and will play it over again. I cried at the end.

reviewText: Guitar hero with paper bugs.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
If you're looking for a short, easy, musical rhythm game, it is this.

Pros:
+ Good soundtrack
+ Unique paper art style
+ Short
+ Easy

Cons:
- No widescreen support, plays in fullscreen with black bars on the sides
- No options menu
- No resolution changing, no mouse sensitivity or audio sliders
- Some might consider it too short for its price tag
- A little bit harsh on your wrist if you're playing with a mouse (Not sure if it supports touch controls on compatible display devices)

Buying it on iOS might be a better idea.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
41 minutes is how long this game is. Take that into consideration.

The game is a steal at the $1.62 price tag, however it's not a game that's meant for adults. Whilst it's relaxing, and the music is incredible, the game posses no challenge, and serves only as a means of building up hand/eye coordination, problem solving skills, rhythm, etc.

The developer most certainly should market this toward children and those with special needs, as it seems like a game that could do a lot of good in those markets, however I would not recommend it for a serious gamer, over the price tag of $2.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Ephemerid is a rythm game telling.
You'll spend one day in the life of a may fly (no spoiler :))
Basically, all the puzzles work the same way: click at the right place & at the right time. Nothing too complicated, but perfecting the whole game can be challenging if you're not playing with a touch-screen. Typically a game that's better to play on a tablet (I played with a mouse)

Let's go straight to the point:
+ Music track perfectly fits the game (of course it does)
+ Relaxing game, you can't fail or die. If you want some challenge, one of the achievents is to perfect the game
+ No text / dialog, but the story yelling is still well done
+ A few different type of puzzles. Could probably be boaring if the game last for hours, but it's not the case
+ The gameplay is simple but very nice, relatively relaxing game...

- ...But I think it probably better fit the touch screens
- I don't think you can find your completion rate anywhere (I may be wrong)
- So short (I finished in about 45 minutes, and I think it's more or less a fixed lenght of time) I wouln't recommend to buy at full price. 1 or 2$ sounds way more reasonable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Ephemerid is such a relaxing and aesthetically pleasing game.
Pretty graphics with simple, no thought needed gameplay and lovely, soothing music...it's a perfect balance.

With no sense or consequence for mistakes, this game is great for calming down and having a moment to yourself.

You'll also probably end up developing a new level of hatred for spiders...they're jerks!

I highly recommend trying out this game for yourself.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It's amazing for such a simplistic concept how emotionally invested I found myself in the 'characters'. Gorgeous artwork, fantastic soundtrack and the sweetest storyline - it's superb.

Can be quite challenging at times, too; don't be fooled too much by the simplicity of the gameplay!

I really enjoyed Ephemerid and I'm so glad I added it to my collection. Well done, guys!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Honestly? Buy the game, if not for the game itself than for its soundtrack. The music in this game practically drips with the passion and effort the artist put into it. Gameplaywise it is a little hard at times to click and drag the mouse fast enough and get into the rhythm based on the various things the game wants you to, but in my opinon it just adds to the fun and challange.

If you're used to playing rhythm games you might find this to be a little easier (if not different) than the standard but there's an option to let you control the speed of the music if it turns out to be easier than you like. Also it shouldn't take you more than an hour, hour-and-a-half to complete the first time around but there is some replay value with the achievements and finding the secret level.

For the story it's a little open to interpetation especially when you play it a second time. I won't spoil anything major but basically after (you, the player) discovering another mayfly, the pair is split up when one is captured in a net and taken away. What follows is a small adventure through the world to an awesome soundtrack with an ending similar to Journey in the sense it manages to loop the story in a plausable way so it feels like a complete story.

TLDR: PRETTY GAME + AWESOME SOUNDTRACK = MY RECOMENDATION TO GET IT

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I don't usually review much, but I had to review this game.
Ephemerid: A Musical Adventure is a creative art piece with classic rock music that will make your guitar skills sound phony and ridiculous as soon you start clicking to the rhythm and embarking on a journey of life as a little mayfly.

It's a simple point and clicking game, an interactive story, it resembles paper cut animation, yet it is enough to tangle you until the very end (worked for me!).
It's not a long game: an hour and a half, maybe, is enough to complete it.

I'd say that the main positive aspect here is the story. Then its papercraft concept. Music tends to be quite repetitive and overwhelming to people who don't appreciate tons of guitars. It was fine to me, though some were a bit cheesy (but that point is related to one's musical taste).
Artwork is simple but it's enough for this game.
A game like this has a lot of possibilities to offer in terms of game design and interactivity, I confess that I was expecting more variety.

Buuuut.. in my humble opinion, it's a beautiful little, interactive, magical experience and it deserves more recognition.
Not only because it's reasonably cheap, also because it will make your day better *tends to return from time to time*

If you like guitars, point and clicking rhythm and narrative altogether, it's a must!
If not..
..you'll love it for its story.

feels. feels everywhere

(Note that this is just my opinion and nothing more than the experience I've had while playing this game)
